AC approves Anthropology Dept. with two conditions
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
The Academic Council has
approved a re commendation
from the administration that a
Department of Anthropology be
created, according to Dr. Jack P.
Greene, a Council member and
author of the proposal.
However, two
conditions,
the selection of a "first rate
man" to be the department
chairman, and adequate funds to
support Anthropology, must be
met before the department's
program can be officially
implemented.
According to Greene, a
member of the committee to find
a department chairman, Richard
Price, associate professor of
anthropology at Yale, would
"probably be the chairman" if he
accepted the position. Greene
noted that Price's decision would
be known by the first of the
year.
"He is an extremely strong
scholar and is known to be
outstanding with undergraduate
and graduate students...he's
superb from every stand. He fits
directly into our Atlantic History
program."
Between $400,000 and
$500,000 will be needed to set
up the anthropology program.
Greene noted that the
Rockefeller Foundation has been
supporting the anthropology
program in the Social Relations
Department of the University for
the past two years, with the grant
specifically designed to get more
anthropological studies on the
campus. Greene pointed out that
the grant "was not designed to

set up anthropology as a separate
department."
Greene was optimistic that
Hopkins would receive the
money from the foundation.
"They (the people who we're
dealing with from the
Rockefeller Foundation) seemed
very encouraging and enthusiastic
over the new Department. We're
very hopeful as such, and we
should know by February of
their decision."
He further stated that
two-thirds of the money which
would be received would go to
the anthropology department
while the remaining third would
go to the History Department.
Dr. Greene and Dr. DysonHudson, former professors of
Social Relations here, originally
received a grant from the
Rockefeller Foundation in 1971.
Approximately $100,000 was
given in the program's
conception for a trial run.
One-half of the money then was
given to the anthropology section
of Social Relations, with the
other half going to the History
Department.
The recommendation to move
the anthropology department out
of the Social Relations
Department came as a result of a
study recently concluded by a
group of three anthropologists at
the request of the Hopkins
administration.
The three, Professor Bernard
Cohn, chairman of the
Anthropology Department at the
University of Chicago, Professor
David Maybury- Lewis, Chairman
of the Anthropology Department

at Harvard, and Professor Sidney
W. Mintz of Yale, the foremost
Caribbean anthropology scholar
in the country" according to
Greene, were given the task of
deciding whether anthropology
should be made into a separate
department.

Basically they fel that
anthropology was in a field of its
own and therefore should be a
separate department.
"The members of the study
thought that anthropology was
very different from Social
Relations, and it deserved to have

a distinct and separate
department of its own...that it
should be in its own separate
house," Greene said.

Course Guide hit at SC meeting
By MARK DALZELL
The Course Guide and its
editor, John Broughton, came
under fire Tuesday evening from
Student Council members
objecting to inaccuracies and
misleading reviews in the Guide's
Fall issue.
Also appearing before the
Council, aside from Broughton,
were David Stam, Librarian at
the MiltonS. Eisenhower Library,
Alan Sapakie, Student Union
Director, and Larry Denton,
Executive Assistant to the
Vice -President for Homewood
Division.
"There is a general trend
irresponsibility in the
toward
Course Guide," Chris Steiner, the
Council's Secretary, asserted her
feelings which seemed to be
shared by the majority of her
Council colleagues. Broughton
was _.ubjected to intense, often
hostile, questioning from a
Student Council which finances
the Course Guide.
Council President Andy Savitz,
who did not personally take part
in the interrogation, read
portions of a letter from Dr.
Roger A. Horn, Chairman of the
Mathematical Sciences

Department, alleging the Course'
Guide's unfair treatment of
courses offered in his
department.
Shen Hoffmann, Senior Class
President, presented a similar
statement given to him by Dr.
George Krotkoff, Chairman of
the Near Eastern Studies
Department. Krotkoff
pinpointed certain obvious
inconsistencies in the Guide's
appraisal of his lecturing ability.
Proposal..
Hoffmann then proposed the
formation of an ad hoc
committee to study and make
recommendations on the future
of both the Course Guide and
Teacher Evaluation. The latter is
a pilot program whose funding
ceases at the end of the spring
term. Hoffmann's proposal was
accepted unanimously.
Stam, accompanied by an
assistant, delivered a short
presentation outlining the
library's financial, storage, and
staff woes. The M.S.E. library,
Stam said, could no longer hold
the University's expanding
collection and this would
necessitate a movement back to
the old Gilman Hall facilities.

That in turn would entail a large
capital expenditure in climate
control equipment.
"I would appreciate any
support you can give to the
magnitude of the library's needs."
Stam said. "The more people
who draw attention to my
problems the better."
S avit z, who has apparently
taken an interest in the library's
plight, indicated as Stam left that
it was his hope th library would
rank high on the Council's list of
priorities next semester.
Denton gave the Council a rundown on the University's
contingency planning to meet
fuel shortages in the coming
months. He held open the
possiblity that a four day class
week may have to- be imposed. In
the meantime he sought the
Council's aid in keeping rumors
from spreading and in Offe ring
suggestions.
Planning for Orientation '74
has already begun and it was that
which brought Sapalcie to the
Council on Tuesday. Council
members appeared particularly
concerned with Sapakie's role in
the informal planning session
now taking place.

Hopkins doesn't establish new academic departments
very often and so the apparent decision of the Academic
Council to approve a proposal by Dr. Jack P. Greene to set
up an anthropology department is doubly welcome.
The addition of a new department, contemplated for
September 1974, provided sufficient funding and a
chairman can both be found, should provide more
flexibility in the study of both sociology and anthropology
on this campus. As President Muller noted ,this week,
problems often arise when two disciplines are contained
within the same academic department. Although there will
no doubt be substantial difficulties to be overcome in the
beginning, it appears that some needed diversity is going to
be added to the Homewood curriculum.
The other welcome aspect of this apparent decision
(apparent because only one member of the Council would
comment on it) is that it shows a willingness on the part of
the Council to consider favorably innovative programs in
the academic area. It was only two years ago that the
Council rejected a proposed University year for ACTION
program because students would receive both academic
credit and pay for work in the community. They also
commented that the proposal was too poorly defined. By
their action this week, the Council has shown a new
willingness to consider innovative programs with an open
mind. Although the department proposal still must be
approved by the Board of Trustees, the Council deserves
congratulation for its favorable reaction to the new idea.
